section.heading: Purpose and Scope.
section.text: This chapter describes the responsibilities of the State Disbursement Unit (SDU) of the Administration for the collection, distribution, and disbursement of child support payments.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Distribution" means the application of collections to appropriate accounts as required by the Social Security Act and regulations issued under the Social Security Act.
"Disbursement" means forwarding payments to the payee of the case.
"Electronic transfer" means the electronic transfer of support payments to a designated account in a financial institution.
The SDU is responsible for the collection, distribution, and disbursement of support payments ordered payable through a court, support enforcement agency, or the SDU.
The Administration shall:
Maintain records of support payments:
Collected;
Distributed; and
Disbursed; and
Adhere to generally accepted accounting principles and procedures.

Bonding Against Loss Resulting from Misappropriation. An employee of the SDU or a support enforcement agency who has access to, or control over, funds collected pursuant to this subtitle shall be covered by a bond against loss resulting from misappropriation.
The SDU may accept support payments made by check, credit card, money order, or electronic funds transfer.
The appropriate support enforcement agency shall furnish a record of payment to a noncustodial or custodial parent upon request.
Dishonored Checks.

When a noncustodial parent's check is dishonored by a financial institution, the SDU shall send a notice to the noncustodial parent demanding payment by certified check or money order within 7 days of the date of the notice.
The SDU may charge the noncustodial parent the cost incurred for processing the noncustodial parent's dishonored check.

section.heading: Distribution and Disbursement of Support Payment Collections.

para.text: The amount of child support collected and due shall be distributed and disbursed as required by the court order and the Social Security Act and regulations issued under the Social Security Act.
The Administration may issue support payments to a custodial parent by electronic transfer.
Before issuing support payments to a custodial parent by electronic transfer, the Administration shall notify the custodial parent of the:
Intention to transmit future payments electronically; and
Exemptions available under §F of this regulation.
Within 30 working days of receiving notification, the custodial parent shall:
Designate an account to which the payments may be sent; or
Claim an exemption as specified in §F of this regulation.

If within 30 days of receiving the notice specified in §C of this regulation, the custodial parent fails to designate an account for electronic transfer and fails to demonstrate that an exemption under §F of this regulation applies, the Administration may:
Establish an account to which payments may be electronically transmitted; and
Provide to the custodial parent any information, identification cards, or other materials necessary to access the funds in the account.
The Administration may not require a custodial parent to receive support payments by electronic transfer if there is a verified hardship in:
Paying the account access fees; or
Accessing the funds due to:
A physical or mental disability;
A language barrier;
A literacy barrier; or
The custodial parent's home and place of work being located more than 10 miles from:
An automated teller machine; or
A financial institution where the account funds can be accessed.
If the payor and the payee of a payment cannot be identified, the SDU shall:
Deposit the payment in the Administration's bank account;
Investigate the nature of the payment to properly distribute and disburse the payment; and
Document unsuccessful attempts to distribute and disburse the payment.
A payment is considered abandoned if the:
Parties are unidentified for 3 years; or
Payment cannot be delivered to the custodial parent and attempts to refund the payment to the noncustodial parent are unsuccessful over a 3-year period.
The Administration shall annually:
Submit a detailed list of all abandoned payments to the Comptroller of the Treasury's Abandoned Property Unit; and
Remit funds covering the total of such abandoned payments to the Comptroller of the Treasury's Abandoned Property Unit.

section.heading: Record Retention.
section.text: The SDU shall retain fiscal case records for each case for the latest of the following periods:

para.text: 3 years from the closing of the case;
The time of closing of any pending audit covering the records;
3 years after receipt of the latest federal tax refund offset; or
5 years after a child support payment has been remitted to the Comptroller as abandoned property.
